Gulf Coney: Large deepwater grouper (Serranidae) found at depths >45m, commercially important species in the Gulf of California known locally as baqueta

Extranjero: Spotted sand bass and parrot sand bass (Serranidae), deepwater species occurring at >100m depth, also known as spotted sand bass

Leopard Grouper: Leopard grouper (Mycteroperca rosacea), reef-associated serranid important for commercial and recreational fisheries

Gulf Grouper: Gulf grouper (Mycteroperca jordani), large endemic serranid, historically important but now depleted due to overfishing

Amarillo Snapper: Amarillo snapper (Lutjanus argentiventris), reef-associated lutjanid found on rocky substrates

Barred Pargo: Barred pargo (Hoplopagrus guentherii), reef snapper important for artisanal fisheries

Groupers and Snappers: Aggregated group of 29 groupers (Serranidae) and 6 snappers (Lutjanidae) not elsewhere included, important predators on reef and rocky habitats

Drums and Croakers: 29 species of drums and croakers (Sciaenidae) including corvinas, important commercial species in the northern gulf

Grunts: Haemulidae family including silvergray grunt, sargo, and related species, reef-associated benthic feeders

Herbivorous Fish: Parrotfishes (Scaridae), rudderfishes, surgeonfishes and other herbivorous species that graze on algal communities

Large Reef Fish: Aggregated group including snake eels, conger eels, triggerfishes, wrasses, cusk-eels, rockfishes, and other large reef-associated species

Small Reef Fish: Aggregated group of damselfishes, blennies, gobies, puffers, moray eels, angelfishes, and other small reef-associated species including bullseye pufferfish (botete)

Small Demersal Fish: Small fish on soft substrate including gobies, sea catfishes, labrisomids, clingfishes, and other species occurring on sand and mud bottoms

Pacific Angel Shark: Squatina californica, nocturnal bottom-dwelling shark species important in artisanal fisheries

Small Migratory Sharks: Smoothhounds (Mustelus spp.) including sharptooth, brown, sicklefin, and gray smoothhound that migrate seasonally into the gulf

Large Pelagic Sharks: Large sharks including thresher sharks, hammerheads, bull shark, white shark, nurse shark, and mako shark, apex predators in the ecosystem

Guitarfish: Rhinobatidae family including thornback, banded, and shovelnose guitarfish, commercially important in artisanal fisheries

Skates Rays and Sharks: Aggregated group of 58 chondrichthyan species including eagle rays, stingrays, electric rays, butterfly rays, horn sharks, and skates

Flatfish: American soles, large-tooth flounders, lefteye flounders, righteye flounders, and tonguefishes, bottom-dwelling species on soft sediments

Mojarra: Gerreidae family including golden, Peruvian, and yellowfin mojarra, important forage fish in coastal and estuarine areas

Scorpionfish: Scorpaenidae and Triglidae families including searobins and scorpionfishes, reef and soft-bottom predators

Lanternfish and Deep: Myctophidae, Stomiidae and Ogcocephalidae including lampfish, viperfish, and batfish, mesopelagic and bathypelagic species important in vertical energy transfer

Totoaba: Totoaba macdonaldi, endemic critically endangered sciaenid, historically important but now protected species

Large Pelagics: Tunas, jacks, dolphinfish, barracudas, and swordfish, migratory pelagic predators important for commercial and recreational fisheries

Mackerel: Scomberomorus species including Gulf sierra and Pacific sierra, seasonally important commercial species

Hake: Merlucciidae including Cortez hake and Panama hake, demersal predatory fish

Small Pelagics: Anchovies (Engraulidae), silversides (Atherinopsidae), and herrings (Clupeidae) including Pacific sardine, forage fish supporting the food web

Mysticeti: Baleen whales including fin whale, gray whale, humpback whale, blue whale, and whale shark, filter-feeding cetaceans migrating seasonally through the gulf

Odontocetae: Toothed whales and dolphins including common dolphins, bottlenose dolphins, sperm whales, and beaked whales, important marine mammal predators

Orca: Killer whales (Orcinus orca), apex predators feeding on marine mammals, fish, and sea turtles

Vaquita: Phocoena sinus, endemic critically endangered porpoise restricted to the northern Gulf of California

Pinnipeds: California sea lion (Zalophus californianus) and harbor seals, marine mammal predators with colonies in the gulf islands

Sea Turtles: Green turtle, loggerhead, hawksbill, and olive ridley sea turtles, protected species using the gulf for feeding and nesting

Seabirds: Brown pelican, boobies, frigatebirds, cormorants, gulls, and terns that nest on gulf islands and feed on fish and invertebrates

Penaeid Shrimp: Brown shrimp, white shrimp, and blue shrimp (Penaeidae), commercially most valuable fishery in the Gulf of California

Crabs and Lobsters: Blue crab (Callinectes bellicosus), swimming crabs, and spiny lobsters, important commercial invertebrates

Cephalopods: Squid and octopus species, important prey for marine mammals, large fish, and seabirds

Benthic Filter Feeders: Bivalves, sponges, tunicates, and other sessile invertebrates that filter water for food particles

Benthic Carnivores: Predatory polychaetes, nemerteans, and other carnivorous benthos feeding on infauna and epifauna

Benthic Grazers: Herbivorous gastropods, urchins, and other invertebrates that graze on microalgae and detritus

Macrozoobenthos Deposit Feeders: Deposit-feeding polychaetes, holothurians, and other invertebrates processing sediment organic matter

Macrozoobenthos Suspension Feeders: Suspension-feeding polychaetes, bryozoans, and hydroids filtering particles from the water column

Large Zooplankton: Copepods, euphausiids, chaetognaths, and other mesozooplankton >200 µm, key link between primary producers and fish

Small Zooplankton: Microzooplankton <200 µm including ciliates, flagellates, and copepod nauplii, grazing on phytoplankton

Jellyfish: Gelatinous zooplankton including scyphozoans and hydrozoans, predators on zooplankton and fish larvae that can form blooms

Large Phytoplankton: Diatoms and large dinoflagellates >20 µm, primary producers supporting the food web during upwelling events

Small Phytoplankton: Nanoplankton and picoplankton <20 µm including cyanobacteria and small flagellates, dominant primary producers in oligotrophic waters

Microphytobenthos: Benthic diatoms and microalgae on the seafloor, important primary producers in shallow waters

Macroalgae: Seaweeds including kelps, red algae, and green algae providing habitat structure and primary production

Seagrass: Zostera marina and other seagrasses forming important coastal habitats and nursery areas in the Colorado River delta region

Detritus: Particulate organic matter from dead organisms and fecal material, important food source for deposit feeders and bacteria

Bacteria: Heterotrophic bacteria decomposing organic matter and recycling nutrients through the microbial loop
